title: Characterization of macrophage infiltration and polarization by double fluorescence immunostaining in mouse colonic mucosa
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Immunofluorescence staining specific for M2-like and total macrophage populations
Timing: 2 days
The main purpose of this step is to obtain the binding between the first primary antibodies specific for i) the membrane receptor CD206, which is expressed mainly in the surface of macrophages with a M2-like phenotype; ii) the pan murine macrophage marker F4/80. This allows the characterization of the immune response profile in the studied tissues.
In order to succeed in the staining procedure, the steps of fixation, permeabilization and blocking of unspecific sites are crucial.
Remove the selected slides from −80°C and allow them to reach room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 20 min.
Draw 2–4 times the hydrophobic barrier around the sections using the hydrophobic marker PAP Pen and let the barrier dry completely for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C). Do not draw too close to the tissue section and do not touch it while drawing the hydrophobic barrier.
Fixation
Place the slides in a slide-holder and cover completely the sections (∼400 μL) with cold acetone (stored at −20°C). Let it dry completely for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Note: this step should be done under the chemical hood.
Rehydrate the tissue in 1× PBS for 10 min by placing the slides in a slide staining jar.
Place the slides in a slide staining jar and wash three times in 1× PBS under gentle shaking, for 5 min each wash (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).

Permeabilization
Remove excess PBS from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.

Cover the sections with 100 μL permeabilization buffer and incubate for 30 min in a humidified chamber containing ddH2O at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Place the slides in a slide staining jar and wash three times in 1× PBS under gentle shaking, for 5 min each wash (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Blocking
Remove excess PBS from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.
Cover the sections with 100 μL blocking buffer and incubate for 30 min in a humidified chamber at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Addition of first primary antibody
Dilute the goat anti CD206 antibody (1:500 v/v) in blocking buffer.
Gently vortex the solution for 2 s at moderate speed.
Remove excess blocking solution from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.
Cover the sections with 100 μL blocking buffer supplemented with anti-CD206 and incubate for 12–16 h in a humidified chamber at +4°C.
Place the slides in a slide staining jar and wash three times in 1× PBS under gentle shaking, for 5 min each wash. (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Critical: Sections must be covered by the solutions during all the incubation times to avoid drying out (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Figure 2. Designing of hydrophobic barrier and coverage of the sections
(A) The hydrophobic barrier retains the liquid solution on the top of the sections. The tissue sections must be always covered.
(B) The presence of the hydrophobic barrier allows to perform different stainings in tissues located in the same slide.

Note: The usage of hydrophobic marker is strongly recommended to avoid the spreading of the staining solution throughout the slide. Moreover, the hydrophobic barrier can be useful to avoid cross-contamination, if different staining solutions are used next to each other in the same slide (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B)
Addition of second primary antibody
Dilute the rat anti-F4/80 antibody (1:100 v/v) in blocking buffer.
Gently vortex the solution for 2 s at moderate speed.
Remove excess PBS from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.
Cover the sections with 100 μL blocking buffer supplemented with anti-F4/80 antibody and incubate for 1 h in a humidified chamber at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Place the slides in a slide staining jar and wash three times in 1× PBS under gentle shaking, for 5 min each wash. (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Addition of secondary fluorescent-conjugated antibodies
Dilute 1:1000 (v/v) the Alexa Fluor® 555-conjugated anti-rat and Alexa Fluor® 488- conjugated anti-goat secondary antibodies in blocking buffer.
Gently vortex the solution for 2 s at moderate speed.
Remove excess PBS from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.
Cover the sections with 100 μL blocking buffer supplemented with secondary antibodies and incubate for 1 h in a humidified chamber at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Place the slides in a slide staining jar and wash three times in 1× PBS under gentle shaking, for 5 min each wash. (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Mounting
Remove excess of 1× PBS from the slides using a wipe (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]). Do not touch the sections.
Place one drop of VECTASHIELD® Antifade Mounting Medium with DAPI on the tissue section.
Lay a microscope glass coverslip on the tissue section.

Remove excess of VECTASHIELD® Antifade Mounting Medium with DAPI at the edges of the slide, avoiding to press the glass coverslip.
Fix the coverslip at the perimeters with nail polish.
Pause point: The mounted slides can be stored at +4°C for one week under protection from light prior imaging.
Note: Fluorophore-conjugated secondary antibodies tend to form precipitates. It is recommended to vortex them prior usage to reduce the risk of fluorescent clamps in the staining procedure, which would interfere with the imaging process.
Microscopy imaging
Timing: it varies according to number of samples and number of desired images for each sample
Adjust the exposure time and gain of each channel blue (DAPI), green (CD206) and red (F4/80) to satisfy the dynamic range of the experiment.
Note: The adjustment should be done from the sample having the highest intensity.
Once the settings are selected, acquire pictures of at least 5 representative fields from each sample on individual blue (DAPI), red (F4/80) and green (CD206) channels.
Multi-channel images can be merged or separated, based on the visualization purposes. ImageJ/FIJI can be utilized for merging or separating the channels of the different pictures.
Critical: It is important to avoid the overexposure of each fluorophore to prevent photobleaching which can compromise the fluorescent signal (it is not recommended to go longer than 1s for exposure time)
Note: Fluorescent staining are not permanent. Therefore, it is recommended to acquire the images of all the samples in the same day to relate any variation of the signal intensity to biological relevance and not to fluorescence stability.
Pause point: described Images can be stored indefinitely prior to analysis.
